Author: polycryptoblog#1173
Content: Is there an easy way to find the largest ( by coin amount ) transaction sent to an address before a certain blockheight.   The only thing I can come up with is to listunspent , pull the json to a sheet and use a function to sort.  I‚Äôm just wondering if I‚Äôm missing something obvious to get this done more simply

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: not listunspent as it could be spent already

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: you would want getaddresstxids

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: filter out all after a blockheight

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: find the biggest

Author: polycryptoblog#1173
Content: Will getaddresstxids work with watch-only addresses? they will be burn addresses so not worried about them being spent

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: as long as addressindex is on, it will work with all addresses, it is what the explorers use

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: once its notarized, its notarized

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: and the node will simply refuse to reorg it

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: now maybe you can disrupt notarizations, but in that case the dpowconfs stays at 1, so everybody knows notarization is not happening

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: so even if you can disrupt notarizations, it doesnt help double spending

Author: Alexfrog#1338
Content:
A question regarding how the Komodo 'correct chain' is determined:    
Generally in most blockchains, the chain with the most cumulative work is considered the correct one.  (Many people think of this as 'longest chain', but this is wrong, a chain that was longer but at lower difficulty could have less cumulative work).  
In Komodo, notary nodes are allowed the chance to periodically produce one block at a low difficulty, to gain their rewards.  This results in notary nodes collectively getting a large portion of the total blocks.   
My question is:  does the best chain in komodo consider these notary node produces blocks as counting as low difficulty for purposes of determining the correct chain?  Or do they count at the same weight as normally mined (high difficulty) blocks?
This is important because if they count at the same weight, then Notary Nodes have a much greater impact on determining the correct chain than they 'should', which one could say was more centralized because notary nodes would have far more ability to determine the best chain than their proof of work would indicate.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: it counts as the difficulty mined, easy diff, so it is not any advantage

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: this issue is only for KMD itself, other chains have no advantages at all for notaries

Author: Mylo#8306
Content:
https://komodoplatform.com/tech-tuesday-update-13/

Centralization comparison to btc/eth/vtc mining 64NN + the 25% of blocks mined non-NN vs a handful of pools in btc etc vtc

Author: Alexfrog#1338
Content: ok, so because notary node blocks are low difficulty, they dont give a group of notaries the ability to 51% attack, or determine which chain or fork to follow.  Thats good.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: the notaries are designed to be as passive as possible

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: they wait for the chain to come to a normal consensus

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: then when the notaries agree on a recent height+hash, they submit this proposed notarization to the network

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: EVERY node then checks to see if that height+hash matches what they ALREADY had locally, then and only then do they change state in any way at all due to the proposed notarization. It adds a dynamic checkpoint to the already existing checkpoint code and also if it detects an attempted reorg of a notarized height, it rejects it

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: so it is a very small surgical change designed to only protect notarized heights that were already on the local node

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: the power of evil notaries would be to NOT notarize, thus smoothly degrading to a non-notarized chain

Author: Alexfrog#1338
Content: Komodo always seems very well designed against attacks, whenever I try to come up with some way its vulnerable, its like you already thought about it. üòâ

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: I foresaw the many chains world and the lack of hashpower to secure them all, so I needed a very efficient way to secure the dozen ecosystem chains. I guess when making something you will depend on yourself, you go the extra mile, but really I just made the fewest changes to an already working system. That seems the best way, especially with consensus systems, where seemingly easy things to do like DAA is full of pitfalls. So if it aint broke, I dont fix it. Which mean just adding to the already existing checkpointing and later when we found some 90%+ hashrate attack needed to specifically prevent reorging notarized chain, we added that. The final aspect that made it as close to 100% protection as I can imagine was the dpowconfs. That simply sets the "confirmations" field to 1, until it is notarized. With that trivial change, exchanges that rely on "confirmations" > N automatically wait for notarizations. We found that exchanges just wont make any changes to their payment processing code, so this was the way to get them to support notarizations without doing anything. And since the main risk of evil notaries is that notarizations can be stopped, the dpowconfs is an automatic detector for that condition

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: we also find that when there are blockchain events, ie. chain split, larger forks, the notaries dont reach consensus themselves and this also triggers dpowconfs to stay at 1. This is a good thing as the last thing you want to do when there is an active chain split is processing any large amounts!

Content: what does `ConnectBlock: Previous logical timestamp is newer Actual[1556369035] prevLogical[1556369035] Logical[1556369036]` mean and what causes it, any ideas?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: probably during connect block, it found that the previous logical timestamp is newer than the current one.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: it is harmless as long as you dont assume timestamps are monotonically increasing

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: i explain in: https://medium.com/@jameslee777/decentralized-trustless-oracles-dto-by-piggybacking-on-timestamp-consensus-rules-2adce34d67b6
